headline: Another swipe at Ohioans’ citizen initiative rights to get constitutional measures on the ballot: editorial - cleveland.com
context: Volunteers with Citizens Not Politicians, the citizens' effort last year to reform Ohio's redistricting system, load boxes of signed petitions to Ohio Secretary of State Frank LaRose's office on Monday, July 1, 2024, in Columbus, Ohio. A new legislative proposal would add new requirements that petition circulators would have to meet, including wearing "paid" badges if they receive anything of value for their efforts. (AP Photo/Patrick Orsagos)AP

annotations.paragraph: Tucked into a 204-plus-page bill pending in Columbus is further evidence that Ohio voters are rattling Statehouse insiders by resorting to statewide ballot issues – which is Ohioans’ constitutional right – to block or overthrow radical legislation.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the bill and its implications for Ohio voters' rights.

annotations.paragraph: Senate Bill 153 is sponsored by Republican state Sens. Theresa Gavarone, of Bowling Green, and Andrew Brenner, of Delaware. As cleveland.com’s Anna Staver reported, “Voting rights groups say the [bill’s proposed] changes will make it harder to bring issues before voters” and “called it a reaction to Ohioans legalizing marijuana and putting abortion protections in the state constitution in 2023.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the bill and reactions from voting rights groups.

annotations.paragraph: The Gavarone-Brenner plan would require anyone who is compensated for circulating an election petition “to wear a badge that identifies the person as a paid circulator,” the nonpartisan Legislative Service Commission reports.
annotations.reason: This paragraph details a specific requirement proposed in the bill.

annotations.paragraph: But in 2004, the Ohio General Assembly enacted a law requiring statewide issue campaigns to report “all money or things” of value paid to petition circulators, as well as such circulators’ names and addresses. Anyone is free to obtain that information from the Ohio secretary of state’s office and to publicize it.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context about existing laws related to petition circulators.

annotations.paragraph: That’s why the Gavarone-Brenner bill is pile-it-on overkill by Statehouse insiders fearful of Ohio voters. It implies that someone paid to circulate a petition is merely seeking money rather than being committed to the candidate or cause the petition supports. But the real issue isn’t a circulator’s motivations but whether broad access to the ability to petition for ballot access helps advance Ohio voters’ option to legislate for themselves. It does. And that’s what scares entrenched Statehouse partisans.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides analysis and opinion on the implications of the bill.

annotations.paragraph: Brenner chairs the state Senate’s Education Committee. Gavarone is the Senate’s majority floor leader, making her the GOP-ruled chamber’s No. 3 Republican. Last year, as an Ohio Ballot Board member, Gavarone skewed the official ballot language for November’s statewide Issue 1, an anti-gerrymandering reform, helping induce its defeat.
annotations.reason: Provides context on key political figures involved in the legislative process affecting citizen initiatives.

annotations.paragraph: Gavarone’s amendment claimed that Issue 1 would require a bipartisan redistricting panel “to gerrymander the boundaries of state legislative and congressional districts.” That’s the exact opposite of what Issue 1 would have done, but Secretary of State Frank LaRose, an Upper Arlington Republican, supported Gavarone’s word play, and the GOP-run Ohio Supreme Court went along.
annotations.reason: Details the misleading language used in the amendment and its political support, relevant to the article's focus on citizen initiative rights.

annotations.paragraph: Defeat of Issue 1 last fall, upholding Ohio’s unfair districts, was the first GOP ballot-issue victory after a string of defeats: In August 2023, voters rejected by 57% to 43% a bid by General Assembly Republicans -- with Gavarone one of two prime co-sponsors – to require a minimum 60% “yes” vote on proposed amendments to the Ohio Constitution. Voters kept the required statewide minimum 50% plus one.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context on recent ballot issues and their outcomes, relevant to the discussion of citizen initiative rights.

annotations.paragraph: Then, in November 2023, in a 57% “yes” to 43% “no” tally, voters initiated and approved a constitutional amendment protecting women’s access to abortion. At that same 2023 election, voters, also 57% to 43%, approved a voter-petitioned law (not a constitutional amendment) to let people age 21 or older possess and use marijuana in Ohio. The General Assembly had long delayed action on recreational marijuana legalization, virtually forcing its backers to go to the statewide ballot. But because the initiative wrote a law, not a constitutional amendment, the General Assembly is free to weaken legalization and has been busily trying to do so.
annotations.reason: Discusses recent voter-initiated measures and legislative responses, relevant to the theme of citizen initiative rights.

annotations.paragraph: As a practical matter, the badges proposed by Gavarone and Brenner wouldn’t much figure in local candidate elections, where petitions are often circulated neighbor-to-neighbor. But badges could impede proposed statewide ballot-issue campaigns, in which issue backers must gather huge numbers of signatures (for example, at least 413,487 statewide to propose a constitutional amendment, with those signatures obtained in at least 44 of the 88 counties.) But that’s the real point of this badging bid.
annotations.reason: Explains the potential impact of the proposed badge requirement on statewide ballot initiatives, directly relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Critics say the broad requirements proposed for petition circulators in SB 153, including that they could be subpoenaed to testify about their work if their petitions are challenged, and would have to wear the “paid” badge for any item “of value” they received, presumably including a slice of pizza, appear designed to scare off signature-gatherers.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the proposed requirements in SB 153 and their potential impact, which is directly relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Gavarone and Brenner’s proposal to require badges may be a pot shot – but it’s a potentially prejudicial one aimed at Ohioans’ 113-year-old right to amend their constitution without interference by Statehouse insiders who like Ohio just the way it is.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers direct commentary on the implications of the proposal, which is relevant to the main premise.
